_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

Information about each Buddha of the pas: Place of awakening of the Buddha
Gatherings of disciples of the Buddha
Parents and capital city of the Buddha
Unfinished conversation among the mendic: The power and might of a Realized One
The ability of the Realized One to recollect the caste, names, clans, life-span, chief disciples, and gatherings of disciples of the Buddhas of the past
The knowledge of the caste, names, clans, conduct, qualities, wisdom, meditation, and freedom of the Buddhas of the past
The reason for the Realized One's ability to recollect all these things
The possibility of deities telling the Realized One about these things
Information about Buddha Vipassī (a mult: Place of awakening of the Buddha
Gatherings of disciples of the Buddha
Parents and capital city of the Buddha
What’s Normal For One Intent on Awakenin: When the being intent on awakening passes away from the host of Joyful Gods, he is conceived in his mother’s womb, mindful and aware.
An immeasurable, magnificent light appears in the world, surpassing the glory of the gods.
Four gods approach to guard the four directions when the being intent on awakening is conceived in his mother’s belly.
The mother becomes naturally ethical when the being intent on awakening is conceived in her belly.
The mother no longer feels sexual desire for men, and she cannot be violated by a man of lustful intent when the being intent on awakening is conceived in her belly.
The mother obtains the five kinds of sensual stimulation and amuses herself, supplied and provided with them when the being intent on awakening is conceived in her belly.
No afflictions beset the mother when the being intent on awakening is conceived in her belly.
Seven days after the being intent on awakening is born, his mother passes away and is reborn in the host of Joyful Gods.
The mother of the being intent on awakening gives birth after exactly ten months.
The mother of the being intent on awakening only gives birth standing up.
Gods receive the being intent on awakening first, then humans when he emerges from his mother’s womb.
Four gods receive the being intent on awakening and place him before his mother, saying: ‘Rejoice, O Queen! An illustrious child is born to you.’
The being intent on awakening emerges already clean, unsoiled by waters, mucus, blood, or any other kind of impurity, pure and clean.
Two streams of water appear in the sky, one cool, one warm, for bathing the being intent on awakening and his mother when he emerges from his mother’s womb.

As soon as he’s born, the being intent on awakening stands firm with his own feet on the ground. Facing north, he takes seven strides with a white parasol held above him, surveys all quarters, and makes a proclamation.
An immeasurable, magnificent light appears in the world, surpassing the glory of the gods when the being intent on awakening emerges from his mother’s womb.
The thirty-two marks of a great man [dn1: Well-planted feet
Thousand-spoked wheels on the soles of his feet
Projecting heels
Long fingers
Tender hands and feet
Graceful clinging of hands and feet
Arched feet
Calves like those of an antelope
Palms of both hands touch the knees when standing upright
Private parts covered in a foreskin
Gold-colored skin with a golden sheen
Delicate skin that doesn't attract dust and dirt
Hairs grow one per pore
Blue-black hairs that curl clockwise and stand up
Body as straight as Brahmā's
Bulging muscles in seven places
Chest like that of a lion
Gap between the shoulder-blades filled in
Proportional circumference of a banyan tree
Cylindrical torso
Excellent sense of taste
Jaw like that of a lion
Forty even teeth with no gaps and perfectly white
Large tongue
Voice of Brahmā, like a cuckoo's call
Deep blue eyes
Eyelashes like a cow's
Tuft between the eyebrows, soft and white like cotton-wool
Head shaped like a turban
After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.
The two possible destinies of a great ma: If he stays at home, he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch, possessing the seven treasures, and his dominion extends to all four sides.
If he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who draws back the veil from the world.
The nurses appointed for Prince Vipassī: Some carried him on their hip
Ability to see for a league all around both by day and by night
The questions asked by Prince Vipassī [d: Why is he called an old man?
Am I liable to grow old?
Am I not exempt from old age?
The response of the charioteer to Prince: Everyone is liable to grow old, including you.
No one is exempt from old age.
The questions asked by King Bandhuma [dn: I hope the prince enjoyed himself at the park?
I hope he was happy there?
The things told by the charioteer to Kin: What Prince Vipassī saw on the way to the park
Prince Vipassī's reaction to seeing the old man
The characteristics of the sick man [dn1: Collapsed in his own urine and feces
Being picked up by some and put down by others
The questions asked by Prince Vipassī [d: Why is he called a sick man?
Am I liable to fall sick?
Am I not exempt from sickness?
The response of the charioteer to Prince: Everyone is liable to fall sick, including you.
No one is exempt from sickness.
The questions asked by King Bandhuma [dn: I hope the prince enjoyed himself at the park?
I hope he was happy there?
The things told by the charioteer to Kin: What Prince Vipassī saw on the way to the park
Prince Vipassī's reaction to seeing the sick man
The characteristics of the dead man [dn1: Making a bier out of garments of different colors
The questions asked by Prince Vipassī [d: Why is that crowd making a bier?
But why is he called departed?
Am I not exempt from death?
Will the king and queen and my other relatives and kin see me no more?
And shall I never again see them?
The response of the charioteer to Prince: Everyone is liable to die, including you.
No one is exempt from death.
The king and queen and your other relatives and kin shall see you no more, and you shall never again see them.
The questions asked by King Bandhuma [dn: I hope the prince enjoyed himself at the park?
I hope he was happy there?
The things told by the charioteer to Kin: What Prince Vipassī saw on the way to the park
Prince Vipassī's reaction to seeing the dead man
The questions asked by Prince Vipassī [d: But why is he called a renunciate?
But why are you called a renunciate?
The response of the charioteer to Prince: He is called a renunciate because he celebrates principled and fair conduct, skillful actions, good deeds, harmlessness, and compassion for living creatures.
The response of the renunciate to Prince: I am what is called a renunciate.
I am called a renunciate because I celebrate principled and fair conduct, skillful actions, good deeds, harmlessness, and compassion for living creatures.
The statement made by Prince Vipassī [dn: Then I celebrate the one called a renunciate, who celebrates principled and fair conduct, skillful actions, good deeds, harmlessness, and compassion for living creatures!
The conditions for cessation of old age: Cessation of the six sense fields
Sentient beings with different qualities: Sentient beings with little dust in their eyes
Sentient beings with much dust in their eyes
Different types of water lilies and lotu: Water lilies that sprout and grow in the water without rising above it
Water lilies that sprout and grow in the water reaching the water’s surface
Water lilies that sprout and grow in the water but rise up above the water and stand with no water clinging to them.
The Buddha Vipassī's teachings [dn14:3.8: Step by step teaching on giving, ethical conduct, and heaven
Explanation of the drawbacks of sensual pleasures and the benefit of renunciation
Explanation of the special teaching of the Buddhas: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path
The response of the king's son Khaṇḍa an: We go for refuge to the Blessed One and to the teaching.
Sir, may we receive the going forth and ordination in the Buddha’s presence?
The Buddha Vipassī's further teachings [: Explanation of the drawbacks of conditioned phenomena and the benefit of extinguishment
Education, encouragement, firing up, and inspiration with a Dhamma talk
The Buddha Vipassī's teachings [dn14:3.1: Step by step teaching on giving, ethical conduct, and heaven
Explanation of the drawbacks of sensual pleasures and the benefit of renunciation
Explanation of the special teaching of the Buddhas: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path
The response of the 84,000 people (a cau: This must be no ordinary teaching and training, no ordinary going forth in which the king’s son Khaṇḍa and the high priest’s son Tissa have gone forth.
The ordination of the 84,000 people [dn1: They asked for and received ordination.
The actions of the 84,000 people who had: They went to see the Buddha Vipassī
The Buddha Vipassī's instructions to the: Wander forth, mendicants, for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
Let not two go by one road.
Teach the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased.
Reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
There are beings with little dust in their eyes. They’re in decline because they haven’t heard the teaching. There will be those who understand the teaching!
When six years have passed, you must all come to Bandhumatī to recite the monastic code.
The instruction of the Buddhas [dn14:3.2: Not speaking ill nor doing harm
Details of the Buddha Vipassī [dn14:3.29: He was born as an aristocrat into an aristocrat family.
He was awakened at the root of a trumpet flower tree.
He had a fine pair of chief disciples named Khaṇḍa and Tissa.
He had three gatherings of disciples—one of 6,800,000, one of 100,000, and one of 80,000—all of them mendicants who had ended their defilements.
He had as chief attendant a mendicant named Asoka.
His father was King Bandhuma, his birth mother was Queen Bandhumatī, and their capital city was named Bandhumatī.
Such was his renunciation, such his going forth, such his striving, such his awakening, and such his rolling forth of the wheel of Dhamma.
He was born as an aristocrat into an aristocrat family.
For you the life-span is short, brief, and fleeting.
A long-lived person lives for a century or a little more.
You were awakened at the root of a peepul tree.
You have a fine pair of chief disciples named Sāriputta and Moggallāna.
You have had one gathering of disciples—1,250 mendicants who had ended their defilements.
You have as chief attendant a mendicant named Ānanda.
Your father was King Suddhodana, your birth mother was Queen Māyā, and your capital city was Kapilavatthu.
Such was your renunciation, such your going forth, such your striving, such your awakening, and such your rolling forth of the wheel of Dhamma.
